edu.calpoly.spritely

Class AnimationWindow

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.calpoly.spritely.AnimationWindow
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GraphicsWindow, SpriteWindow

    public abstract class AnimationWindow
extends java.lang.Object
    An AnimationWindow controls the animation of a screen. SpriteWindow provides an animation window for a grid of tiles, and offers a text mode. GraphicsWindow gives unconstrained animation.

    • Method Detail

      • setFps

        public void setFps(double fps)
        Sets the number of frames/second that are displayed.
        Parameters:
        fps - The desired number of frames per second
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_FPS

      • setSilent

        public void setSilent(boolean silent)
        Sets a flag to silence warnings that are sent to the terminal, such as when animation falls behind. This flag defaults to false. The flag can be changed at any time.
        Parameters:
        silent - true if you don't want to get warnings.

      • setKeyTypedHandler

        public void setKeyTypedHandler(KeyTypedHandler handler)
        Sets a key typed handler. If a key is typed, the key typed event will be be sent to the handler during a call to waitForNextFrame(). It is forbidden to call waitForNextFrame() or showNextFrame() from within the body of a handler.
        Parameters:
        handler - The handler.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called, or if a handler was previously set.
        See Also:
        SpriteWindow.waitForNextFrame(), GraphicsWindow.waitForNextFrame()

      • setMouseClickedHandler

        public void setMouseClickedHandler(MouseClickedHandler handler)
        Sets a mouse handler. If the mouse is clicked, the mouse event will be sent to the handler during a call to waitForNextFrame(). It is forbidden to call waitForNextFrame() or showNextFrame() from within the body of a handler. Note that SpriteWindow scales the x an y coordinate so that they refer to the row and column of a tile square, not pixels.
        Parameters:
        handler - The handler.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called.
        See Also:
        SpriteWindow.waitForNextFrame(), GraphicsWindow.waitForNextFrame()

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Returns true if this animation window is running . An animation window can be stopped by calling stop(). Additionally, it is stopped if the current thread is interrupted, e.g. while waiting for when the next animation frame is ready.
        Returns:
        true iff we're running
        See Also:
        Thread.interrupt(), stop()

      • getTimeSinceStart

        public double getTimeSinceStart()
        Give the time since the start of the animation of the current animation frame, in milliseconds. This value can drift off of wall clock time, if the animation is too slow. This can also happen if the program is suspended for a time, e.g. for debugging. It is therefore recommended that all time-based events in an animation be based off the time value returned by this method, rather than e.g. System.nanoTime().

        If the system can't keep up with the frame rate, it will drop up to four frames. Past that limit, it will print a diagnostic message to stdout, and "pause" the animation (that is, it will not advance getTimeSinceStart() even though the wall clock time indicates that it "should").

        Returns:
        The total elapsed time, adjusted for pauses, in milliseconds.
        See Also:
        pauseAnimation(int), setSilent(boolean), System.nanoTime()

      • start

        public void start()
        Start this window. This may only be called once per window.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were already started

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stop this AnimationWindow's animation, and close the window, if it's visible.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were never started

      • pauseAnimation

        public void pauseAnimation(int pauseMS)
        Pause the animation for the given time, and reset the animation clock. Resetting the animation animation clock makes the framework's idea of when the animation started agree with the current frame number. This avoids having the framework skip frames or print out a warning message if a frame has to wait for something lengthy, like user input. After the long delay, a call to pauseAnimation(0) will reset the animation clock.

        Pausing the program might also be useful for debugging. This is particularly true in text mode, since the screen's cursor is constantly being sent to the home position, which tends to scramble debut output.

        Returns immediately if the animation stops, e.g. because the window is closed.

        Parameters:
        pauseMS - The number of milliseconds to pause. A value of 0 potentially resets the animation clock, with no pause. A value less than zero causes an immediate return, with no effect.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we haven't been started
